subject: Re: [junit] JUnit fossilized at 3.8.1?
msgSnippet: JB, do you have more contacts than us? Could you do a little asking around? Failing that, perhaps this group could decide what it really wanted and then make
messageBody:
JB, do you have more contacts than us? Could you do a little asking around?

Failing that, perhaps this group could decide what it really wanted
and then make the changes and release a 3.8.2? I mean, it's not like
we don't have some of the finest testing brains on the planet around
here (self _not_ included), not to mention some very strong opinions
(ok, I'm in this category). Just a wild Friday afternoon kind of
thought.

On 6/3/05, J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains@...> wrote:
> jason r tibbetts wrote:
> > I spent some time looking at both www.junit.org and
> > junit.sourceforge.net, and it seems as though JUnit development has been
> > frozen in time. For example, the JUnit Web page seems to have had few
> > updates since 2003. And on SourceForge, Erich Gamma and Kent Beck
> > responded to some GUI-related RFEs with the comment that because most
> > IDEs now handle test running themselves, there's no point to improving
> > JUnit's own GUI tools. Non-interface bug reports and RFEs have gone
> > unassigned unless they're of very high priority (such as ones related to
> > thread safety). Is there simply no real demand for improvements, or has
> > the SourceForge bug report page been deprecated?
>
> That's an ongoing debate in the community. I honestly believe that the
> JUnit framework is closed (in the Open/Closed Principle sense), even if
> the test runners are occasionally inadequate. Since I use Eclipse's test
> runner most of the time and Ant's the rest of the time, that's not an
> issue for me.
>
> JUnit 4.0, complete with support for Java annotations, is in the works,
> but I don't know any more than that.
> --
> J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
> Diaspar Software Services
> http://www.diasparsoftware.com
> Author, JUnit Recipes: Practical Methods for Programmer Testing
>
